snippet: The reported deal with the International Atomic Energy Agency will offer inspectors access to two more sites, but it is not a formal part of the broader talks on Iran’s nuclear program.
abstract: International Atomic Energy Agency says that Iran has agreed to resolve all outstanding issues with the agency and will allow international inspectors 'managed access' to two important nuclear facilities that have not been regularly viewed; promise of wider scrutiny does not extend to the Parchin military site, one of the most contentious locations.

byline.original: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and DAVID E. SANGER
byline.contributor: Alissa J. Rubin reported from Paris, and David E. Sanger from Washington. Alan Cowell contributed reporting from London.

lead_paragraph: The reported deal with the International Atomic Energy Agency will offer inspectors access to two more sites, but it is not a formal part of the broader talks on Iran’s nuclear program.

headline.main: Iran Says It Has Agreed to ‘Road Map’ With U.N. Agency on Nuclear Inspections
headline.print_headline: Iran Says It Has Agreed to ‘Road Map’ With U.N. Agency on Nuclear Inspections
